title: ‘It’s a mess’: Race and gender fault lines in Virginia cripple Democrats
authors: Marc Caputo, Maggie Severns, Caitlin Oprysko
content:
RICHMOND , Va. — Democrats couldn ’ t react fast enough to the racist photo in Virginia Gov . Ralph Northam ’ s old yearbook showing one man dressed as a Klansman and another in blackface .
But a newly surfaced sexual assault allegation against the man who would replace Northam if he resigns — Justin Fairfax , the state ’ s African-American lieutenant governor and a rising star in the party — has left Democratic national figures and Virginia lawmakers at a loss for words .
The back-to-back stunners in Richmond exposed fault lines in the Democratic Party coalition that were unimaginable just five days ago . And with the state ’ s political hierarchy in the balance , the stories triggered a potential collision of two powerful forces in Democratic politics — the battle to combat racism and the movement to stop sexual harassment .
Swift to condemn Northam on Friday , Democratic presidential hopefuls ducked for cover on Tuesday . Sen. Bernie Sanders clung to an apparent cellphone call in the Capitol to avoid a reporter ’ s questions about Fairfax . Other Democratic senators — who both condemned Northam and said it was imperative to “ believe the woman ” when Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh was accused of sexual harassment — have gone silent , too .

“ I ’ m really not going to comment , ” said Tina Tchen , past chief of staff for former first lady Michelle Obama and a co-founder of a new legal defense group for sexual harassment victims called Time ’ s Up .
“ I don ’ t know enough about Virginia , ” she said . “ The stories are certainly messy and if you want me to comment about the lieutenant governor , I don ’ t know enough . ”
Tchen added later that “ the TIME ’ S UP Legal Defense Fund takes the accusations of all survivors seriously and so should everyone else . ”
Fairfax has called the allegation a politically motivated “ smear ” timed to damage him on the cusp of the governorship .
In Richmond , Democratic lawmakers who over the past five days pushed for Northam ’ s resignation were quietly milling around the state capitol on Tuesday , ducking out of legislative sessions via side doors to avoid the media and responding to questions with “ no comment. ” With Northam showing no signs of resigning , and Democrats and Republicans alike unsure of how to respond to the emerging sexual assault claim against Fairfax , lawmakers tried to avoid the scandal .
Late in the day on Tuesday , Democrats in the Legislature issued a joint statement responding to the harassment allegation , saying that “ the facts here are still being determined . ”
“ Every individual deserves the opportunity to be heard , and we respect anyone who comes forward to share their story , ” the statement read .
The state ’ s Democratic senators , Tim Kaine and Mark Warner , who have both called on Northam to resign , expressed a need for caution in response to the allegation against Fairfax . “ With respect to the situation with the lieutenant governor , I just don ’ t know enough information , ” Kaine told CNN on Tuesday .
“ He has seen the reports and that the lieutenant governor denies anything nonconsensual occurred , ” a Warner spokesperson told ███ . “ Senator Warner believes every allegation deserves to be heard and taken seriously . ”
A major difference between the two controversies — Northam ’ s blackface and the assault claim against Fairfax — is the nature of the evidence .
Northam initially admitted Friday he was one of two young men depicted in blackface or a Klan outfit on his 1984 medical school yearbook page . He then recanted that admission at a news conference Saturday afternoon , saying he had donned blackface to imitate Michael Jackson on another occasion at a talent show .
With respect to the sexual assault allegations , there is a dispute over what happened between Fairfax and his accuser , though both agree they had a sexual encounter . She told The Washington Post that Fairfax forced her to perform sexual acts on him during the Democratic National Convention in 2004 . The Post could not corroborate the story and initially chose not to publish it . A social media post about the incident was later leaked to the website Big League Politics and published online .
Fairfax has repeatedly denied the allegation , first in a statement posted overnight on Monday in which he said he has “ never assaulted anyone. ” He has called the allegation “ completely false ” and said that he kept in touch with the woman after the incident .
███ is not naming the accuser out of respect for her privacy . She has hired the law firm of Katz , Marshall and Banks , which represented Kavanaugh accuser Christine Blasey Ford .
Democrats ’ wait-and-see approach to handling the allegation against Fairfax reflects an unpleasant truth : The party has no playbook for how to respond to claims of sexual harassment or assault .
“ It ’ s a mess , ” said one consultant who has been communicating with the lieutenant governor ’ s team . “ And it ’ s indicative of challenges we face in 2020 when we talk about race and gender and balancing the two . It ’ s emblematic of what ’ s to come . ”
There are also practical concerns over how the party will proceed in Richmond in the coming weeks . Fairfax was widely expected to replace Northam if the latter resigned from office . If he is not able to replace Northam , then Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring is the most likely replacement if both the governor and lieutenant governor were to resign from office .
Such a situation is unimaginable to Virginia operatives , especially with Northam resisting the drumbeat of calls to resign . But the sudden uncertainty about the line of succession has fed a sense of paralysis within the state Capitol about what ’ s next and how to respond .
An attorney who briefly represented another Kavanaugh accuser , one-time Democratic presidential hopeful Michael Avenatti , said Ford gained credibility by the way she calmly and clearly spoke out publicly against Kavanaugh , which gave rise to Democrats ’ “ believe the woman ” mantra . He said he would reserve judgment in Fairfax ’ s case , but acknowledged there ’ s a disparity in the reaction to the two cases because of partisan politics .
“ There ’ s no question that it ’ s incredibly difficult for her to come forward , especially in a high-profile situation such as this , ” Avenatti said when asked about the challenges presented by a progressive African-American woman accusing a black Democratic politician of sexual assault .
Avenatti said Fairfax ’ s accuser needs to be heard from . But he said the situation is risky .
“ It takes someone to have incredible courage because they put their life on the line , both literally and figuratively , ” Avenatti said . “ Their lives are never the same . ”

RICHMOND, Va. — Democrats couldn’t react fast enough to the racist photo in Virginia Gov. Ralph Northam’s old yearbook showing one man dressed as a Klansman and another in blackface.

But a newly surfaced sexual assault allegation against the man who would replace Northam if he resigns — Justin Fairfax, the state’s African-American lieutenant governor and a rising star in the party — has left Democratic national figures and Virginia lawmakers at a loss for words.

The back-to-back stunners in Richmond exposed fault lines in the Democratic Party coalition that were unimaginable just five days ago. And with the state’s political hierarchy in the balance, the stories triggered a potential collision of two powerful forces in Democratic politics — the battle to combat racism and the movement to stop sexual harassment.

Swift to condemn Northam on Friday, Democratic presidential hopefuls ducked for cover on Tuesday. Sen. Bernie Sanders clung to an apparent cellphone call in the Capitol to avoid a reporter’s questions about Fairfax. Other Democratic senators — who both condemned Northam and said it was imperative to “believe the woman” when Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh was accused of sexual harassment — have gone silent, too.

So have activists.

“I’m really not going to comment,” said Tina Tchen, past chief of staff for former first lady Michelle Obama and a co-founder of a new legal defense group for sexual harassment victims called Time’s Up.

“I don’t know enough about Virginia,” she said. “The stories are certainly messy and if you want me to comment about the lieutenant governor, I don’t know enough.”

Tchen added later that “the TIME’S UP Legal Defense Fund takes the accusations of all survivors seriously and so should everyone else.”

Fairfax has called the allegation a politically motivated “smear” timed to damage him on the cusp of the governorship.

In Richmond, Democratic lawmakers who over the past five days pushed for Northam’s resignation were quietly milling around the state capitol on Tuesday, ducking out of legislative sessions via side doors to avoid the media and responding to questions with “no comment.” With Northam showing no signs of resigning, and Democrats and Republicans alike unsure of how to respond to the emerging sexual assault claim against Fairfax, lawmakers tried to avoid the scandal.

Late in the day on Tuesday, Democrats in the Legislature issued a joint statement responding to the harassment allegation, saying that “the facts here are still being determined.”

“Every individual deserves the opportunity to be heard, and we respect anyone who comes forward to share their story,” the statement read.

The state’s Democratic senators, Tim Kaine and Mark Warner, who have both called on Northam to resign, expressed a need for caution in response to the allegation against Fairfax. “With respect to the situation with the lieutenant governor, I just don’t know enough information,” Kaine told CNN on Tuesday.

“He has seen the reports and that the lieutenant governor denies anything nonconsensual occurred,” a Warner spokesperson told POLITICO. “Senator Warner believes every allegation deserves to be heard and taken seriously.”

A major difference between the two controversies — Northam’s blackface and the assault claim against Fairfax — is the nature of the evidence.

Northam initially admitted Friday he was one of two young men depicted in blackface or a Klan outfit on his 1984 medical school yearbook page. He then recanted that admission at a news conference Saturday afternoon, saying he had donned blackface to imitate Michael Jackson on another occasion at a talent show.

With respect to the sexual assault allegations, there is a dispute over what happened between Fairfax and his accuser, though both agree they had a sexual encounter. She told The Washington Post that Fairfax forced her to perform sexual acts on him during the Democratic National Convention in 2004. The Post could not corroborate the story and initially chose not to publish it. A social media post about the incident was later leaked to the website Big League Politics and published online.

Fairfax has repeatedly denied the allegation, first in a statement posted overnight on Monday in which he said he has “never assaulted anyone.” He has called the allegation “completely false” and said that he kept in touch with the woman after the incident.

POLITICO is not naming the accuser out of respect for her privacy. She has hired the law firm of Katz, Marshall and Banks, which represented Kavanaugh accuser Christine Blasey Ford.

Democrats’ wait-and-see approach to handling the allegation against Fairfax reflects an unpleasant truth: The party has no playbook for how to respond to claims of sexual harassment or assault.

“It’s a mess,” said one consultant who has been communicating with the lieutenant governor’s team. “And it’s indicative of challenges we face in 2020 when we talk about race and gender and balancing the two. It’s emblematic of what’s to come.”

There are also practical concerns over how the party will proceed in Richmond in the coming weeks. Fairfax was widely expected to replace Northam if the latter resigned from office. If he is not able to replace Northam, then Virginia Attorney General Mark Herring is the most likely replacement if both the governor and lieutenant governor were to resign from office.

Such a situation is unimaginable to Virginia operatives, especially with Northam resisting the drumbeat of calls to resign. But the sudden uncertainty about the line of succession has fed a sense of paralysis within the state Capitol about what’s next and how to respond.

An attorney who briefly represented another Kavanaugh accuser, one-time Democratic presidential hopeful Michael Avenatti, said Ford gained credibility by the way she calmly and clearly spoke out publicly against Kavanaugh, which gave rise to Democrats’ “believe the woman” mantra. He said he would reserve judgment in Fairfax’s case, but acknowledged there’s a disparity in the reaction to the two cases because of partisan politics.

“There’s no question that it’s incredibly difficult for her to come forward, especially in a high-profile situation such as this,” Avenatti said when asked about the challenges presented by a progressive African-American woman accusing a black Democratic politician of sexual assault.

Avenatti said Fairfax’s accuser needs to be heard from. But he said the situation is risky.

“It takes someone to have incredible courage because they put their life on the line, both literally and figuratively,” Avenatti said. “Their lives are never the same.”
